item.title: Archangel
item.description:
Kelly Johnson’s drawings of the Archangel designs alongside Convair’s competing Fish and Kingfish concepts.


The A‑1 was Lockheed’s first attempt at a U‑2 successor. It was essentially a paper study with a long fuselage and conventional wings, but it lacked the performance needed to outrun Soviet defenses. It showed Johnson’s team was thinking about speed and altitude but hadn’t yet solved the radar visibility problem.

item.title: Facts You May Not Know About U.S. Aviation
item.description:
Throughout the 20th century, the United States achieved countless innovations in aviation. From Orville and Wilbur Wright’s first flight at Kitty Hawk, NC, to today’s advanced aircraft, there have been milestones that would have seemed impossible to the generation before.

I break down my favorite airplanes into three eras: World War II and before, the Cold War, and Modern Day. I know that’s a small number of categories compared to the full scope of aviation advances, but I’m organizing them this way as I start building my website. My goal is to generate as many stories as possible so there’s plenty of content for everyone. Believe me when I say this page will continue to grow with ongoing updates and additions.

item.title: The Amazing SR-71
item.description:
The Blackbird

Many people don’t realize there were actually two aircraft nicknamed the Blackbird. The first was the A‑12, built by the CIA as a single‑seat reconnaissance aircraft. It was designated “A‑12” because it was the twelfth design in the Archangel series — “Archangel” being the program’s code name.

Lockheed and Convair competed to build a replacement for the U‑2, which had become vulnerable to Soviet radar and missiles. The CIA initially favored Convair’s Kingfish design, but Lockheed’s A‑12 offered better specifications at lower cost. Track record mattered too: Convair’s B‑58 Hustler had been plagued by delays and overruns, while Lockheed had delivered the U‑2 on time and under budget.

item.title: SR-71 Specifications
item.description:
General Characteristics

Dimensions and Capacities

Specification Value
Crew 2
Length 107 ft 5 in (32.74 m)
Wingspan 55 ft 7 in (16.94 m)
Height 18 ft 6 in (5.64 m)
Wheel track 16 ft 8 in (5.00 m)
Wheelbase 37 ft 10 in (12.00 m)
Aspect ratio 1.7
Wing area 1,800 sq ft (170 sq m)
Empty weight 67,500 lbs (30,617 kg)
Gross weight 152,000 lbs (68,946 kg)
Max takeoff weight 172,000 lbs (78,018 kg)
Fuel capacity 12,219 US gal (46,255 L)
Powerplant 2 × Pratt & Whitney J58

Context

  • The SR‑71’s crew of two (pilot and reconnaissance systems officer) was essential: one flew the aircraft, the other managed sensors and navigation at extreme speeds.
  • Its length of 107 feet made it longer than a Boeing 737, yet its wingspan of only 55 feet gave it a sleek, dart‑like profile optimized for supersonic flight.
  • The aspect ratio of 1.7 shows how stubby the wings were — designed for speed, not maneuverability.
  • The fuel capacity of over 12,000 gallons was necessary because the J58 engines consumed fuel at astonishing rates. Even then, the SR‑71 often required multiple aerial refuelings during missions.
  • The Pratt & Whitney J58 engines were unique: they operated as turbojets at lower speeds but transitioned to a hybrid turbojet/ramjet mode above Mach 2.5, allowing sustained Mach 3+ flight.

Performance

Specification Value
Maximum speed 1,910 kn (2,200 mph)
Maximum Mach Mach 3.3+
Ferry range 2,824 nmi (3,250 mi)
Service ceiling 85,000 ft
Rate of climb 11,820 ft/min
Wing loading 84 lbs/sq ft

Context

  • The SR‑71’s maximum speed of 2,200 mph meant it could outrun threats rather than dodge them. Pilots often joked that “speed was life.”
  • Its Mach 3.3+ capability wasn’t just a headline number — the aircraft could cruise at those speeds for hours, something no other operational jet has matched.
  • The service ceiling of 85,000 feet placed it well above most surface‑to‑air missile envelopes and fighter interceptors. Pilots reported seeing the curvature of the Earth and the deep black of space.
  • A rate of climb of nearly 12,000 ft/min allowed the SR‑71 to reach operational altitude quickly, minimizing exposure during takeoff and ascent.
  • The wing loading of 84 lbs/sq ft reflected its design trade‑off: small wings for speed meant high wing loading, making the aircraft less agile but perfectly suited for straight‑line reconnaissance runs.

Notes

  • All dimensions are approximate.
  • Weights reflect a typical operational configuration.
  • Speeds represent maximum achievable under optimal conditions.

Context

  • The SR‑71’s numbers don’t tell the whole story. Its titanium skin expanded several inches during flight due to heat, which is why the aircraft leaked fuel on the ground — the seals only tightened at high speeds.
  • The aircraft’s performance envelope was so extreme that even routine missions required careful planning of refueling points, weather conditions, and threat assessments.
  • Despite its complexity, the SR‑71 flew for over 30 years without ever being shot down, cementing its reputation as one of the greatest engineering achievements in aviation history.

item.title: The Blackbird Family Comparison
item.description:
✈️ Blackbird Family Comparison: A-12, YF-12, and SR-71

The Blackbird family represents one of the most remarkable lineages in aviation history. Born from Lockheed’s Skunk Works during the height of the Cold War, these aircraft pushed the limits of speed, altitude, and stealth. The A‑12, YF‑12, and SR‑71 were closely related in design but served very different missions: clandestine CIA reconnaissance, high‑speed interception, and long‑range USAF strategic reconnaissance. Together, they showcase how a single airframe concept evolved into multiple specialized roles — each breaking records and shaping aerospace engineering for decades to come.
